item.title: Ninja Gaiden 4, Keeper, Pax Dei, and More Added to Xbox Game Pass This Month
item.content:encoded:
Xbox has confirmed the next batch of games coming to Xbox Game Pass for October 2025, which is also the first batch of titles to come in under the new changes Microsoft and Xbox recently made to the service, specifically the fact that prices were raised by 50% for a Game Pass subscription.

Twelve games will join the now more expensive subscription service over the course of October, with three titles set to exit the service; as the cycle is always that with new games entering, old games leave. Some of the highlights for games entering this month include Ninja Gaiden 4, the first new entry in the Ninja Gaiden series in years, which is also launching into the service for those subscribed to the top Ultimate tier of Game Pass.

Ball x Pit is another of the 12 games that is launching into the service on day one, with Double Fine Productions' new game, Keeper, rounding out the three games launching into Xbox Game Pass this month.

Other titles not launching day one into the service, but still notable, include the return of Ninja Gaiden 2 Black, Evil West, Pax Dei, Eternal Strands, and a preview for RPG auto-battler, He Is Coming.

Here's a list of all the games arriving in Game Pass this month, the dates they'll come, where they're playable, and which tiers they'll be available for, since each tier now only gets access to a certain number of games.

  • Supermarket Simulator - October 8 - Cloud, Xbox One, Xbox Series X/S, PC - All tiers
  • Baldur's Gate and Baldur's Gate II Enhanced Editions - October 9 - PC - All tiers
  • The Casting of Frank Stone - October 14 - Cloud, Xbox Series X/S, PC - All tiers
  • Ball x Pit - October 15 - Cloud, Xbox One, Xbox Series X/S, PC - Game Pass Ultimate, PC Game Pass
  • The Grinch: Christmas Adventures - October 15 - Cloud, Xbox One, Xbox Series X/S, PC - All tiers
  • Eternal Strands - October 15 - Cloud, Xbox Series X/S, PC - Game Pass Premium/Ultimate
  • He Is Coming (Game Preview) - October 15 - PC - Game Pass Premium/Ultimate
  • Ninja Gaiden 2 Black - October 15 - Cloud, Xbox Series X/S, PC - Game Pass Premium/Ultimate
  • Pax Dei - October 16 - PC - All tiers
  • Keeper - October 17 - Cloud, Xbox One, Xbox Series X/S, PC - Game Pass Ultimate, PC Game Pass
  • Evil West - October 21 - Cloud, Xbox One, Xbox Series X/S, PC - All tiers
  • Ninja Gaiden 4 - October 21 - Cloud, Xbox Series X/S, PC - Game Pass Ultimate, PC Game Pass

As far as the game's leaving the service this month, as of October 15, Game Pass subscribers can say goodbye to Coccon, Core Keeper, and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutants Unleashed.

Follow Wccftech on Google or add us as a preferred source, to get our news coverage and reviews in your feeds.



https://wccftech.com/ninja-gaiden-4-keeper-pax-dei-xbox-game-pass-october-2025/

item.title: Vampire Survivors gets online co-op this autumn, even if its devs know "no one plays together anyway"
item.content:encoded:
Online video games! They're the future of the medium! Or, I guess they're already here, but still, online co-op is very much in Vampire Survivor's future. It's a feature that's been promised for a little while now, and developer Poncle have shared a little look at it, as well as a confirmation as to when you can expect it: autumn! This autumn, to be precise, which we're currently experiencing, though a more specific window of time wasn't provided.

In a short but sweet little trailer, which shows how all you need to do to make a game online is by pressing the online button (that fabled button far too many people think is effectively real), Poncle showed the simple steps you need to take to go online. You start by setting up a lobby with a unique ID, and when your friends (or enemies) start to join, it'll show you what DLC is and isn't available to play through, presumably depending on whether everyone involved owns a specific piece or not.

The wait is nearly over üó£Ô∏è

Online co-op is coming to Vampire Survivors on PC and consoles THIS Autumn! (yeah it's autumn right now shh) üçÇ

‚ö†Ô∏è dial-up tones will not be included

come back next week for another new announcement! üëÄ pic.twitter.com/NEK0aWr1rS

‚Äî Vampire Survivors ü¶á Emerald Diorama OUT NOW üßÑ (@poncle_vampire) October 7, 2025

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

After that, everyone selects their character of choice, and you get to surviving vampires! There's also a short, jokey comment that I genuinely find quite fascinating: "We know no one plays together anyway lmao." This doesn't surprise me! As someone who's put a good few hours into Vampire Survivors, I can't see the appeal of playing with someone else in the slightest, it's a game I play to completely shut off - perhaps shutting off with someone else is the appeal for some, or just having something other than a fidget cube to play around with in your hands while yapping on Discord.

And yet, this feature still exists, because clearly either enough people have asked for it, no matter how small a number, or Poncle wanted the option there for anyone who might ever want it. There's a value in options like these, options for requests that come from the minority, and as long as they can be completed relatively sustainably, I hope we see more of them. Yes, I know I'm reading too much into what is obviously a joke! That is the curse called writing, I'm afraid.

In any case, Poncle also said there's another announcement coming next week which looks like it has something to do with someone in a crappy skeleton custom in the woods. There's also a visual suggestion that there'll be more announcements in the weeks following that one, so I guess there's big plans for update 1.4 you'll have to keep an eye out for!



https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/vampire-survivors-gets-online-co-op-this-autumn-even-if-its-devs-know-no-one-plays-together-anyway

item.title: Stop Relying On Game Creators To Validate Your Player Choices
item.content:encoded:
One of the many consequences of modern fandom‚Äôs obsession with ‚Äúcanon‚Äù is that stories that have open-ended themes or choices are now held to a new standard of scrutiny. Swaths of the video games we play are about choice, whether that be in the weapons we wield or the sacrifices we make; however, because the internet has become fixated on listing events in bullet points on wikis, the act of making choices and watching the consequences unfold isn‚Äôt enough. Some players want to be ‚Äúright,‚Äù and they want video games and their creators to tell them so. Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is not primarily a choice-based game, but it does offer one at the very end that changes the story entirely. Since the RPG launched back in April, fans have debated the merits of both outcomes, but because a sequel is coming and some people need validation, the developers at Sandfall Interactive have come out and said there is no ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù ending.

Clair Obscur ends in one of two ways, depending on whether or not the player chooses to play the final duel as either the paintress Maelle or Verso, the painted version of her deceased brother. In an interview with Lits Play, Clair Obscur lead writer Jennifer Svedberg-Yen spoke about how both endings of the game are valid and were made with purpose. Neither was meant to be the ‚Äúother‚Äù or ‚Äúwrong‚Äù choice.

‚ÄúI tell everyone there is no ‚Äòcorrect‚Äô ending, there is no ‚Äòcanon‚Äô ending, there is no ‚Äòofficial Sandfall‚Äô ending,‚Äù Svedberg-Yen said. ‚ÄúBoth endings are there for a reason; we put them both there for a reason; they were designed in a very particular way. Neither is perfect. Both are heartbreaking in their own ways. Both of them have parts that make you glad, parts that you feel like, ‚Äòokay, I want a happy ending for these characters,‚Äô but both of them also have their own cost. It‚Äôs a reflection of reality. You know, a lot of times, some people‚Äôs happiness does come with its costs. Things are very rarely perfect. And I think we were really trying to also show both sides of the story.‚Äù

She‚Äôs right. Obviously, the debate over which is the morally correct answer is a whole different discussion. I personally chose the Maelle ending because it felt thematically appropriate, while also understanding that the Verso choice is probably the one that provides the most closure. Both have their merits and drawbacks, and one of the rewarding things about choice-based games is that we get to argue about those forever. However, this modern need to have these decisions declared ‚Äúcorrect,‚Äù either by the text or by the developers, has added an often dismissive layer to those discussions. 

To some extent, this goes back to an attachment players have to their own ‚Äúcanon.‚Äù If a sequel like Infamous Second Son chooses one of its predecessor‚Äôs endings to build off of, it raises questions about the other choice. Why was it there if it was going to be cast aside? What does it say about players who chose the other option? Were they wrong? Was any debate about the morality or merits of that choice for nothing? This is a cloud that has been hanging over the next Mass Effect game for nearly a decade, as the remnants of BioWare have to figure out how they‚Äôre going to make a fifth game set in the Milky Way that either works for all of Mass Effect 3‚Äôs galaxy-defining final choices, or picks one and moves the timeline forward from there.

BioWare is an interesting example to point to when it comes to this dilemma, because even though the Mass Effect and Dragon Age communities love to throw around terminology like ‚Äúcanon‚Äù to refer to specific choices that are chosen by default if players don‚Äôt import a world state or save from a previous game, the studio doesn‚Äôt view it that way at all. The team has even said it would rather not acknowledge a decision in a sequel like Dragon Age: The Veilguard than contradict it. This allows players to feel like their world state is valid, even if they‚Äôre not staring the ramifications of it in the face every game. 

Maybe it‚Äôs because I grew up spending a lot of my early roleplaying days working within the gaps that developers didn‚Äôt fill, but I‚Äôve never looked for confirmation from games that I was ‚Äúright‚Äù when I made a decision.  The need for a game or developer to justify what you‚Äôve done suggests that making choices in games is about aligning your actions with the ‚Äútrue vision‚Äù of the developers, rather than actually expressing your own agency within the story. I almost always treat roleplaying in games as an opportunity for self-reflection. It‚Äôs a big part of why I make myself in character creators. These are my stories, and I‚Äôll write them how I want. I‚Äôd rather a developer not pat me on the head and tell me everything I did was ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù or aligned with canon; that‚Äôs not what it‚Äôs about, and it shouldn‚Äôt be a factor in our decision-making process.

Perhaps the uncertainty about ‚Äúwhat really happened‚Äù is too much for some people. For me, that flexibility, the co-existence of multiple possibilities and my ability to shape which way things go, is the best part of when games give me that autonomy.  But the best choice-based games are the ones we‚Äôre still debating years later, not the ones for which the developers have retroactively decided which was the ‚Äúone true choice.‚Äù So shoutout to Sandfall Interactive and Svedberg-Yen for sticking beside the decision they handed players, rather than capitulating to some imagined idea of ‚Äúcanon.‚Äù I hope they stay true to that in the inevitable sequel.



https://kotaku.com/clair-obscur-expedition-33-ending-choice-canon-correct-2000633292

item.title: Alienware Aurora Gaming Desktop With NVIDIA RTX 5070 Gets Hundreds Off as Amazon Clears Out Stock in Prime Day‚Äôs Final Hours
item.content:encoded:
Building a gaming PC can be a rewarding experience. I can also be frustrating as all hell. Sometimes, it is better to just get something that‚Äôs already assembled. It saves time both on shopping side of things when you‚Äôre trying to source each part you need as well as after it arrives. No delicate assembly. No headache-inducing cable management in the case. No dropping screws off the table and having them roll under the couch. Just take it out of the box and and start downloading Hades II. Right now for Prime Big Deals Days, you can save quite a big on a pre-built gaming PC. The Alienware Aurora gaming desktop has dropped by 17%. That‚Äôs doesn‚Äôt sound like a lot, but it‚Äôs taking the price down from $1,845 to just $1,535. You‚Äôll save $310. That extra cash can buy an Xbox Game Pass Ultimate subscription for‚Ä¶ just shy of one year? Wow, Microsoft needs to get a grip.

See at Amazon

Top-tier Gaming Versatility

Let‚Äôs talk specs. This Alienware gaming PC tower is powered by an Intel Core Ultra 7F processor and is packing the NVIDIA GeForce RTX 5070 graphics card. You‚Äôll be able to play any modern AAA game and even be able to push the settings quite a bit, maintaining a high and stutter-free framerate. It can even handle livestream your gaming to Twitch or YouTube.

You get a whopping 32GB of RAM plus a whole 1TB of storage. That‚Äôs a ton of space to get your started downloading all sorts of games off Steam, the Epic Games Store, or any of the other PC gaming storefronts. This build will also prove to perform reliably outside of gaming. Graphics and processor intensive workflows will be breezy on this machine. Touch up large files in Photoshop or edit together videos in 4K without a problem.

If you‚Äôre worried about overheating, this PC employs a 240mm heat exchanger which uses liquid cooling on the CPU to heighten thermal resistance. That should keep the temperatures relatively low during longer gaming sessions. It‚Äôs well ventilated allowing for efficient airflow, cooling and acoustics.

It wouldn‚Äôt be a capital G ‚ÄúGaming‚Äù PC without some RGB lighting. You can create and edit the AlienFX lighting across the whole ecosystem using the free Alienware Command Center software.

During Prime Big Deals Days, this RTX 5070 gaming PC from Alienware has come down by a dramatic $310. Get it for just $1,535 for a limited time before the Amazon sales event is over.

item.title: A Universal Time (AUT) Codes (October 2025)
item.content:encoded:
A Universal Time is an action-adventure game within Roblox, boasting core RPG elements and a world that‚Äôs been heavily inspired by Jojo‚Äôs Bizarre Adventure and other similar anime stories. A Universal Time requires players to explore a large world and gain powers along the way. Alongside their exploration of the map, they will be required to take on various opponents, including NPCs as well as real players. Although the biggest inspiration for A Universal Time is Jojo‚Äôs Bizarre Adventure, with the game including many of the anime‚Äôs ‚ÄòStands‚Äô, it also showcases characters from other popular anime, including Dragon Ball, One Piece, and more. 

You will have to progress through the game to get stronger and unlock more powerful moves, and for newer players to the game, that can be a daunting task. With both PvP and PvE fights involved, getting ahead of the competition fast is of utmost importance, and using codes is a good way to make some quick progress. A Universal Time codes give players various rewards in the game, including Skin Chests, UCoins, UShards, and more, all of which will come in handy to the average player.

With this in mind, we encourage players to bookmark this page, as any new codes or expirations will be updated here immediately. item.title: Battlefield 6 Servers 'Should Be' Ready for Friday's Release Date, Says Producer ‚Äî Open Beta 'Helped Gauge the Interest'
item.content:encoded:
Battlefield 6's servers are ready for launch day on Friday, one of the game's developers has insisted.

Battlefield lead producer at DICE, David Sirland, replied to a question on X/Twitter about server readiness with a sort of confident sounding "should be!"

"We are planning for [servers to be ready], of course," Sirland said, "and open beta helped gauge the interest as well."

He's not wrong about the beta helping to gauge interest. Battlefield 6 became the series' biggest beta ever, hitting a peak concurrent user count of 521,079 players on Steam alone, resulting in a lengthy queue for those trying to get into August's open beta. Whether or not the full, paid release will garner such a draw remains to be seen ‚Äî but we'll find out one way or the other on Friday.

Battlefield 6 has a release date of October 10 for PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X and S. Check out the Battlefield 6 global release times if you want to know when you'll be able to play in your timezone. Season 1, meanwhile, kicks off October 28 and will deliver additional maps, guns, vehicles, and more, with additional updates planned for November 18 and December 9. And here's some of the gameplay tweaks and balance changes coming with the Battlefield 6 day one patch.

While you wait to play, check out IGN's Battlefield 6 Campaign Preview, and find out what we think of Battlefield 6 Multiplayer. And don't forget, a free-to-download battle royale mode is expected to launch later in October.
Based on our time with the Battlefield 6 beta, we‚Äôve got a BF6 Beginner‚Äôs Guide and Tips, plus the best Battlefield 6 Loadouts and how to use the Range Finder, deploy the Bipod, and how to turn off Haptic Feedback in Battlefield 6.

Vikki Blake is a reporter for IGN, as well as a critic, columnist, and consultant with 15+ years experience working with some of the world's biggest gaming sites and publications. She's also a Guardian, Spartan, Silent Hillian, Legend, and perpetually High Chaos. Find her at BlueSky.

item.title: Amazon Knocks Alan Wake 2 Deluxe Edition for PS5 Down to Its Lowest Price Yet During Prime Big Deal Days
item.content:encoded:
This game is a must-play if you‚Äôre a Remedy fan, especially at this price.

The second day of Prime Big Deal Days is underway, and Amazon isn‚Äôt slowing down just yet. There‚Äôs still plenty of discounts for Prime members to look through, including a ton of video game deals. One of our favorite games from 2023, Alan Wake 2, has even dropped to a new all-time low price at the retailer.

The PS5 version of the Alan Wake 2 Deluxe Edition is currently on sale at Amazon for $39.99 during the October Prime Day sale event, a 33% discount from its retail price of $59.99. This is the lowest price it‚Äôs dropped to yet, so if you‚Äôve been hoping to pick it up, now‚Äôs a great time to do so.

Alan Wake 2 Deluxe Edition (PS5) for $39.99

Alan Wake 2 Deluxe Edition - PlayStation 5

The Deluxe Edition is an excellent pick-up as well, coming with the base game, The Night Springs and Lake House expansions, cosmetics and items (including the Nordic Shotgun Skin for Saga, Crimson Windbreaker for Saga, Celebrity Suit for Alan, Parliament Shotgun Skin for Alan, and Lantern Charm for Saga,) and the Digital Edition of Alan Wake Remastered.

We‚Äôre very big fans of Alan Wake 2. Not only was it a nominee for IGN‚Äôs Best Game of 2023, but our review at the time gave it a glowing 9/10. Reviewer Tristan Ogilvie said it, ‚Äúdelivers one of the boldest and most brain-bending survival-horror storylines this side of Silent Hill 2, presents it with uniformly immaculate art direction and audio design, and reinvigorates the series‚Äô signature light-based shooting as though it‚Äôs been locked and loaded with a fresh pack of Energizers.‚Äù No better time than now to grab it while it‚Äôs at an all-time low price.

More October Prime Day Video Game Deals

There are plenty more PS5 game deals to explore during this final day of Prime Big Deal Days, including great discounts on Death Stranding 2 and Split Fiction. And if you're curious about what other platforms have on sale right now, check out our breakdown of every Xbox game included in Amazon's Prime Big Deal Days sale and 10 Prime Big Deals Day discounts every Switch 2 owner should consider to see even more offers.

Hannah Hoolihan is a freelancer who writes with the guides and commerce teams here at IGN.

item.title: Bethesda Announces Fallout Day Broadcast for October 23 ‚Äî but Are Any Megatons Planned?
item.content:encoded:
A Boone for production.

Bethesda has announced a showcase for its annual Fallout Day on October 23.

October 23, 2077 is of course the day in the Fallout timeline the bombs fell, sparking The Great War that caused the irradiated wasteland fans of the franchise have been playing in over the last few decades.

The Fallout Day Broadcast will stream live on October 23 at 10am PT / 1pm ET / 6pm UK, with the FalloutforHope post-show following immediately after.

In a statement, Bethesda said fans can expect ‚Äúthe latest news about our existing Fallout games, community celebrations, and upcoming fan events.‚Äù

üìÖ Save the date! Our annual #FalloutDay Broadcast will be streaming live on October 23 at 1pm ET, with the FalloutforHope post-show immediately following.

Tune in for the latest news about our existing Fallout games, community celebrations, and upcoming fan events! pic.twitter.com/hOSbioXena

‚Äî Fallout (@Fallout) October 8, 2025

There was no specific mention of news about upcoming games, but fans are already wondering what the company might have Fallout related up its sleeve. There are all sorts of rumors floating around about potential Fallout remakes now that The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion Remastered is out the door (Fallout 3 Remastered was leaked back in 2023, but those plans may have changed). And we know Bethesda plans to eventually get to Fallout 5, albeit after The Elder Scrolls 6.

Perhaps it‚Äôs more likely that we‚Äôll get further updates on Fallout 76, which just announced the upcoming Burning Springs update and the addition of The Ghoul from Prime Video‚Äôs Fallout TV show, featuring the likeness and voice work from Walton Goggins himself. It‚Äôs also worth noting that Season 2 of Fallout, which is set in New Vegas, is due out this December, so maybe we‚Äôll get a new trailer or images.

The last we heard on Fallout 5, by the way, was back in June 2024, when Bethesda Softworks head Todd Howard said he wasn‚Äôt interested in rushing it out the door. Howard opened up about the future of the hit post-apocalyptic RPG series during an interview with YouTube content creator MrMattyPlays.

"For other Fallout games in the future, you know, obviously I can‚Äôt talk about those right now, but I would say, sort of rushing through them, or we kind of need to get stuff out that is different than the work we‚Äôre doing in 76‚Ä¶ we don‚Äôt feel like we need to rush any of that," he said. "The Fallout TV show fills a certain niche in terms of the franchise and storytelling."

The last mainline Fallout game was Fallout 4, which released in 2015. DLC content for the entry was steadily released for PC and consoles over the next year, and in 2018, Bethesda launched its multiplayer-centered offshoot, Fallout 76. While fans slowly flocked to the West Virginia-set open-world RPG, it wasn‚Äôt until the premiere of Prime Video‚Äôs Fallout TV show that the Bethesda series reached a new level of attention.

Fallout Season 2: Who's Confirmed to Return and Who's New?

Still, Howard wouldn't budge when it came to desires for a substantial video game release. For him, it comes down to wanting to treat Bethesda's franchises with care.

"Totally get the desire for a new kind of mainline single-player game," he said. "And look, those things take time. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs bad for people to miss things. We just want to get it right and make sure that everything we‚Äôre doing in a franchise, whether it‚Äôs Elder Scrolls, Fallout, or now Starfield, that those become meaningful moments for everybody who loved these franchises as much as we do."

Wesley is Director, News at IGN. Find him on Twitter at @wyp100. You can reach Wesley at wesley_yinpoole@ign.com or confidentially at wyp100@proton.me.

item.title: Baby Steps‚Äô Manbreaker Did Not Break Me
item.content:encoded:
I‚Äôve been trying to climb the side of this sheer cliff face for several hours using only my feet. The path is tricky and winding but at this point I know the footholds better than the faces of some of my friends. Some of them involve slightly shimmying my feet on a thin ridge of rock. Others involve lifting my leg out from the cliff face, swinging it over, and planting my foot until I feel something firm enough to lift my body up. I misjudge a step, my character tumbles; his body ping pongs back and forth between the side of the path and the conveniently built spiral stairwell next to the path, his head catching the green steel railing. I feel numb at this point. My character groans, gets up, I try again. This is the Manbreaker in Baby Steps, an unpleasant task that I have been told I do not need to do. 

This article contains some plot spoilers for Baby Steps.

Baby Steps is the latest game from Gabe Cuzzillo, Maxi Boch, and, of course, Bennett Foddy. You may know Foddy from QWOP, GIRP and Getting Over It, games infamous for abstracting movement so that the player will often cartoonishly fall down.  It follows an emotionally stunted thirty five year old man named Nate (played by Cuzzillo) who is stuck in a cocoon of permanent social isolation. Nate smokes a lot of weed, lives in his parents' basement, watches One Piece, and eats a lot of pizza. Suddenly he is Isekai‚Äôd from his couch to a surreal, looping, mountainous world that gradually slopes upwards to a mountain top. A helpful man named Jim (played by Foddy) attempts to explain the situation to him and give him shoes, but Nate refuses any help, instead insisting he‚Äôs just gonna go. The only thing he wants is to find a toilet because he needs to pee quite badly and refuses to pee outdoors.

Like QWOP, Baby Steps approximates natural movement in a way that feels stilted and unnatural at first. Whereas QWOP binds your thighs to the Q and W and your calves to O and P on the keyboard, Baby Steps binds the act of raising your left and right legs to L2 and R2 respectively, with trigger depth determining how much you raise your leg. A raised leg is then moved using the left analogue stick. This, along with Returnal, is one of the few games that uses the Adaptive Triggers on the DualSense beautifully as it adds real texture to the sensation of walking. When you actually get good at using your legs, the sensation of walking feels organic in a jarring way.

Baby Steps hit me at a strange time in my life. I currently have a broken foot with several pins sticking out of it. I have been sleeping on my couch since early August so that I can properly elevate my leg and not disturb my girlfriend‚Äôs sleep. I am a month into using a prosthetic crutch that is not unlike a peg leg, a device that forces you to learn how to walk again in a stilted and alien way, but one that becomes second nature over time. I even went to a four day techno festival in nature that I have been going to for over a decade because my pride refused to let the broken foot win. The experience was brutal on my body, yet rewarding. I frequently climbed a steep incline to my cabin and crossed a treacherous floating bridge over a lake using trekking poles to stabilize myself. People kept offering help that I often refused. I was alarmed by how quickly I parsed Baby Steps‚Äô internal logic. 

Throughout the game, Jim constantly offers Nate help. He is like a bodhisattva, a sherpa whose only purpose in this world is to help the others get to the top of the mountain. And yet, through a combination of anxiety and stubbornness, Nate steadfastly refuses to outwardly accept help. His repeated rebukes of Jim builds throughout the entire game, and Nate‚Äôs bullshit attitude and awkwardness increasingly wear away at Jim‚Äôs patience. As you climb the mountain, going from biome to biome, you eventually see Jim‚Äôs masterpiece in the distance: a 250 story green spiral staircase (seemingly based on a real one in the Taihang mountains) that he built for all the hikers to get to the top of the mountain easily. 

Jim is pleased with his staircase. It helps a lot of people achieve their goal of climbing up the mountain where they had previously toiled. But Nate is Nate, and he does not want to take it, instead pointing to a winding and dangerous mountain path. 

JIM: ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt, it‚Äôs too hard for you.‚Äù

NATE: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that hard.‚Äù

JIM: ‚ÄúThey call it the Manbreaker.‚Äù

NATE: ‚ÄúThe Manbreaker?‚Äù

JIM: ‚ÄúYeah, because many men have been broken trying to get up that thing.‚Äù

Nate boasts that he‚Äôs going to do it while Jim tells him if he does that he‚Äôs going to be bashing his head against the Manbreaker for the next five years. This devolves into childish bickering, with Jim forbidding Nate from climbing the stairs, insisting that if and when he gives up on the Manbreaker, he must call Jim ‚Äúlord,‚Äù because he is the lord of the stairs. 

Narratively this is a beautiful setup. Baby Steps is ultimately a game about swallowing your pride and accepting help, but one that fills itself with many totally optional challenges. It can be a brutally difficult game, but it is often only as hard as you want it to be. Nate has fucked you here a little bit, because he is objectively in the wrong and should just take the stairs. But Jim is being a dick, something he has every right to be given Nate‚Äôs behavior. It‚Äôs not that I wanted Nate to win, I just had to know what happened if Nate actually pulled that off. So my long journey on the Manbreaker began.

The Journey Begins

What makes the Manbreaker so punishing is not that the individual steps are harder than what you‚Äôve faced, it‚Äôs that there‚Äôs a lot of them. The cliffs are constructed in a way that if you fall you are unlikely to go further than the base of the stairs, but you will often have to start from the beginning. Individual steps are just difficult enough to seem doable with a handful of distinct choke points in between. If you know what you are doing and don‚Äôt miss a single step, you can scale the entire thing in about twelve to twenty minutes. The real problem lies in landing every step, not slipping once.

There‚Äôs an annoying slope that requires you to quickly scurry early on that will regularly cause you to slide off until you figure out the momentum of a scurry step. Sometimes the game gives you multiple ways to approach the same obstacle: one challenge right before the halfway point can be solved either by shimmying in a narrow ledge to your right or, more consistently I discovered, by placing your foot on a tiny outcropping to the left of the rock and swinging your legs over a few ledges back and forth twice.

At the halfway point through the climb, either on the stairs or the Manbreaker, you will receive one of two cutscenes. Both involve Mike, a friendly hiker also played by Foddy who you have interacted with in the past. If you are on the stairs, Mike will be on the Manbreaker. He says Jim told him not to take the stairs, saying ‚ÄúMike, you‚Äôre ready.‚Äù He feels confident in how far he has come in his abilities and expounds on the rapturous, sublime nature of climbing the path. Nate says the stairs are pretty good too. If you are on the Manbreaker, Mike instead is on the stairs. He asks you why you are doing that, and instead suggests you give up and take the stairs. No matter what path you take, the game tests your conviction by suggesting you are taking the wrong one. 

My girlfriend watched with a combination of bewilderment and schadenfreude as I subjected myself to this over several evenings. ‚ÄúOh yeah you see you should not have done that,‚Äù she would chime in when my foot slipped and I tumbled hundreds of painful feet. At first I would get exceedingly pissed off whenever I fell off. And yet every time I fell off, I got less pissed. As the number of falls increased and I memorized my footholds, I realized that the Manbreaker was teaching me Baby Steps at a higher level. The frustration subsided. The Manbreaker could not hurt me. I locked in. 

On locking in

When I lock in, I think of a particular edit from streamer Northernlion. He is playing The Game of Sisyphus, a game clearly indebted to Foddy‚Äôs Getting Over It. The video is a supercut of him shouting a mixture of zenlike phrases and Instagram grindset guy advice. He is attempting to push the rock up the hill while the song "paranoia" by Kentenshi (itself a remix of the song "Young Girl A") plays. Northernlion‚Äôs advice is sublime and contradictory, punctuated by an aggressive drum machine and distorted Vocaloid samples. It is a speech that seems to suggest that everything is possible and nothing is possible, that your actions are both meaningless and, simultaneously, the only point in the world. If you listen to it enough times, you begin to reconcile those contradictions. On an even longer timeline, it begins to resemble a prayer.

‚ÄúLock in. Lock in. Get it twisted,‚Äù Northernlion begins. ‚ÄúIf you lock in you can do anything. Motherfucker. Get it twisted, your actions impact nothing, your fate is predetermined, the only thing that you can change is your reaction to it. You can do anything you set your mind to, the world is a playground designed for you and only you to achieve your highest level ambitions. If you wait 90 minutes to wake up until you drink your first cup of coffee, nothing can stop you. If you duct tape your mouth when you fall asleep, nothing can stop you. Get it twisted. You are a pawn in a universe chess match. You mean nothing to God if they even exist. You‚Äôre a rounding error. You‚Äôre two pennies on a Fortune 500 company‚Äôs balance sheet; they don‚Äôt care about you in the slightest. Get it twisted. Everybody gets what they deserve in this life. If you put in effort you can achieve anything. Successful people are better people. Get it twisted! The circumstances of your birth determine where you are going to go. Nothing else matters at all: your own level of education, your attitude, your level of effort, your friends, your network, your business, your credentials. Motherfucker!‚Äù 

Those words swirled around in my head with every attempt, their contradictions becoming a centering hum. Waves of frustration would hit me, subside, and the words would redouble my resolve. Nothing was preventing me from leaving, but I could not leave. I had spent too much time studying the cliff face, learning its contours, the end was in sight. I would finish this. Lock in. Get it twisted. 

Other broken men

I was not the only broken man attempting the Manbreaker. As I was throwing myself off the mountain I saw others attempt this. Frequent contributor Ian Walker was being punished by the path, as was Giant Bomb‚Äôs Jeff Grubb, who streamed his attempts and got to the top before I did.

‚ÄúI was already really into Baby Steps by the time I got to the manbreaker, and I was already onboard with the game's central metaphor (as I see it),‚Äù Grubb told me. ‚ÄúThat is that all you can control in life is the next step that you take. Even if you're not that great at taking steps, that's the only option you have. Even if you get lost, that's the only option you have. So just take the next step, and eventually you'll take enough steps and you can look back and say: look how far I've come.When I got to the Manbreaker, it felt like the culmination of that idea but also an argument against it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think a lot of people will take the cutscene between Jim and Nate at the Manbreaker as a challenge to take the Manbreaker. But I definitely took it as a challenge to take the stairs‚Äîto ask for help,‚Äù he said. "Someone built this tool to help me get to where I'm going, but the toxic individualism‚Äîthat has fueled me in life and that has been ingrained in me by my culture‚Äîwouldn't let me.‚Äù

‚ÄúI need to feel like I did it on my own,‚Äù Grubb continued. ‚ÄúAnd I think that's actually a weakness. A flaw inserted into me strategically by a ruling class that does not want me to rely on others because then we might actually start working together.‚Äù

Mercy in design

For as intricate and brutal as the design of the Manbreaker is, it is also compassionate. Each time you hit a new part of the Manbreaker you have to learn the encounter, and by the time you get to the upper layers of it, the prior parts begin to be tedious. But halfway through the run, at the point where you talk to Mike, the stairwell and path become close enough to almost touch for two levels. It is possible to give up on the Manbreaker at this point and take the stairs, or to use the stairs as a shortcut for finishing the end of the Manbreaker. If you decide to take the shortcut after you‚Äôve already gotten the cutscene, the game does not penalize you for this and gives you the same outcome as if you had done it in one go. This is how both Jeff Grubb and I attempted the final climb. I refuse to call anybody "lord," but I‚Äôm old enough to know that repeating the bottom wasn‚Äôt proving anything.

The last series of steps in the Manbreaker are by far the worst in the whole run. The first step requires you to place your foot gently on a declining slope, let your body slide for half a second, then catch the platform with your other foot. You could spend an hour just mastering the timing of this one step. But the game dispenses this complex task with a small kindness, and positions most of these steps save the last few over your previous path. If you fall, you will more than likely have a second chance.

This is the end

(SPOILERS FOR THE END OF THE MANBREAKER/STAIRS BELOW)

This scenario has two potential endings. If you swallow your pride and take the stairs the whole way up, you are ambushed by Jim at the top. He is glowing and smug and makes you call him lord. He gives you a little ribbon and proclaims you are in an elite club called ‚ÄúJiminny‚Äôs Crickets,‚Äù and the game gives you an achievement for this, almost condescendingly.

If, on the other hand, you decide to take the Manbraker then Nate arrives at the top gasping and gloating. Jim is confused, unable to comprehend how Nate did it. Nate boasts that the climb was easy and suggests that perhaps the stairs were superfluous.

‚ÄúBut if the stairs are superfluous then maybe‚Ä¶Jim was superfluous,‚Äù Jim says in a broken voice, adding, ‚ÄúLord.‚Äù 

Jim then proceeds to throw himself off the cliff face (he is probably fine considering everyone in this world is immortal.). Nate broke a helpful man‚Äôs spirit, shattered Jim‚Äôs purpose in life, learned nothing about accepting help, and the game gives you no achievement for it.

As toxic as it is, the Manbreaker felt worth it. After learning to carefully bottle up and regulate my emotions, triggering the cutscene caused a rush of relief to flood through my body all at once. The Manbreaker did not break me, but it changed me significantly. It is not simply a crucible of difficulty, but a beautifully written and designed riddle about rancid pride and sublime challenge chiseled directly into the cliff face. To beat it transforms you into a Baby Steps climbing god just as the game reaches its logical conclusion.

‚ÄúWhat do you do now?‚Äù my girlfriend asked. 

‚ÄúI guess I‚Äôll just finish the game,‚Äù I responded, and climbed to the game‚Äôs conclusion at a breezy, unworried pace.

Correction, 10/8/25, 12:55pm--An original version of this article occasionally misstated the name of character Jim.

item.title: Fallout Day 2025 Broadcast Announced for October 23
item.content:encoded:
Today, Bethesda Game Studios announced that the Fallout Day 2025 broadcast would be streamed live on October 23, 2025, at 1 PM Eastern Time via YouTube, Twitch, and Steam. Bethesda said fans can tune in to learn new information and announcements about 'existing Fallout games, community celebrations, and upcoming fan events'. October 23 is no random date: it's when the two-hour-long nuclear exchange between the United States and China led to the post-nuclear setting of Fallout.

When Bethesda mentions existing games, the mind immediately goes to Fallout 76, since it's the only franchise game that gets regular updates. However, Fallout 76 just got a major reveal, with the deep dive of the Burning Springs update. In December, Bethesda Game Studios will release a major land expansion, bringing Fallout players to Ohio for the first time in the franchise. The new region draws heavily on Fallout 3 and New Vegas aesthetics, aiming to recapture the feel of a harsh, depraved wasteland seen in those games.

Then there's the introduction of The Ghoul, the character played by Walton Goggins in the TV show, who is coming to the game and will introduce the bounty hunting feature with tiered contracts (grunt and head hunts). Bethesda hopes this will create ongoing, repeatable content that encourages both solo and cooperative play. The randomization of contract locations and the public event nature of head hunts foster community interaction and provide a robust source of rewards, addressing players‚Äô desires for challenging but rewarding activities.

There might be some additional tidbits about the Burning Springs update to be shared in the upcoming Fallout Day broadcast, but by and large, the reveal for Fallout 76 already happened. As such, franchise fans are already hoping to hear something about the long-rumored Fallout 3 remaster, as that might fall under 'existing Fallout games'. Of course, it's always possible that Bethesda has just found a new platform to launch Fallout 4 on, like the Nintendo Switch 2.

Follow Wccftech on Google or add us as a preferred source, to get our news coverage and reviews in your feeds.



https://wccftech.com/fallout-day-2025-broadcast-announced-october-23/

item.title: Blink Video Doorbell Is Almost Free, Amazon Offloads Its Own Brand at a Loss
item.content:encoded:
Amazon has made serious moves into home security with its Ring and Blink brands and gives homeowners accessible ways to monitor their properties without professional installation. If you want a doorbell camera that‚Äôs effective, affordable and lets you keep tabs on everything happening at your front door, Blink is the way to go. The newest model of the Blink video doorbell just hit a record low price of $34 (down from $69) for Prime Big Deal Day, and this deal ends tonight. It‚Äôs exclusively available to Prime members.

See at Amazon

Two Years‚Äô Worth of Battery Life Redefines Everything

The larger pain point with doorbell cameras is often the power issue: Hardwired versions demand electrical work that the average person would like to do without, and battery-powered versions require charging every few weeks. The Blink video doorbell eliminates this nuisance with a two-year battery life on two AA lithium batteries. Consider that: you install it once and don‚Äôt mess with it again until the year 2027. No climbing ladders to haul it down to charge, no panic should it die on vacation, no maintenance woes.

The camera provides a vertical field of view that captures people from head to toe which matters more than you might think. Standard doorbell cameras often cut off packages left on the ground or miss the tops of tall visitors‚Äô heads. This full-body perspective means you see delivery drivers placing packages, kids trick-or-treating, or anyone approaching your door in complete context. The 1080p HD resolution delivers clear images during daylight, and infrared night vision switches on automatically after sunset to maintain visibility in complete darkness.

The integrated Sync Module Core (see picture above) is the control center and connects your doorbell to the home‚Äôs Wi-Fi network and facilitates all communication between the doorbell and the phone version of the Blink app. It is simple to plug the module into a standard outlet somewhere in your home and get the doorbell connected to the phone. Should the button be pressed or motion be detected, the event is captured by the module, then triggers an instant notification on the device.

Detection areas let you decide what areas will cause recording: If the doorbell is pointing at the busy street, then you can mask that section off so cars passing by don‚Äôt jam your phone with unimportant notifications. Focus the detection zone on your sidewalk and porch, then receive notifications for activity that is relevant. You can customize the sensitivity via the app which gives you the freedom to decide just how much movement will trigger a recording.

The doorbell is controllable via Alexa voice control and can be integrated with other compatible Alexa devices. Ask Alexa to display your front door and the feed is shown on Echo Show devices around your house.

At just $34, that is a 50% off deal and the lowest price on this model ever. Make sure you don‚Äôt miss it before it runs out of stock.

See at Amazon



https://kotaku.com/blink-video-doorbell-is-almost-free-amazon-offloads-its-own-brand-at-a-loss-2000632081

item.title: Forget the Previous Low Prices, This Govee TV LED Backlight Is Going for Peanuts at Almost 50% Off
item.content:encoded:
We‚Äôre deep into Prime Big Deals Days now ‚Äî Amazon‚Äôs two-day sales even where you can save a bunch of cash on products across every category. It‚Äôs a great time to pick up that espresso maker you‚Äôve been eyeing or that bidet your brother have been trying to convince you to get for months. Something you might have been waiting on for a discount is one of those TV backlights. Good news, the Govee Envisual TV LED Backlight T2 is one of the Prime Big Deals this week and you can save as much as 46%.

There are three different sizes to match however big your TV is. The 11.8-foot light strip is sized for TVs between 55 inches and 65 inches. The 16.4-foot light strip is made for TVs between 75 inches and 85 inches. Then the 21-foot light strip is for your mega mondo-sized TVs at 98 to 100 inches.

See at Amazon

For shorthand, we‚Äôll call them small, medium, and large. The small set normally priced at $140 has come down to $75. The medium dropped from $170 to an even $100. And then the big boy large light strip is down from $220 to just $150.

Synchronize Color

The way the Govee light strips work is a camera sensor is placed on the top of your TV. This model actually has a dual-camera sensor to more accurately capture the color on screen. It then takes that color and assigns them around the light strip which you‚Äôve installed behind your TV around the edge. Each light strip has 60 LEDs per meter and they glow matching the color on screen as if to extend your viewing across the wall and room.

You can customize how your Govee Envisual TV LED Backlight T2 looks. Using the app, manually adjust the saturation of the lighting effects to either be super vibrant or more subtle. Go with whichever fits the vibe of what you‚Äôre watching. It works well with movies, shows, or even video games. Casting the vibrant colors of each new zone you come across in Hollow Knight: Silksong can dramatically enhance your experience.

Combine the backlight LED with other Govee products such as wall or corner lamps. Have all the lights in your home synchronize to what‚Äôs on screen, bathing you and your living room in colorful light.

Get your set of the Govee Envisual TV LED Backlight T2 on sale today for as low as just $75. Discount will be for as much as 46% at least through Prime Big Deals Day.

See at Amazon

item.title: Game Pass Members Get All These New Perks Soon
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Microsoft has announced a new perk for Xbox Game Pass subscribers. Starting October 15, Game Pass members can get a new DLC bundle for Call of Duty: Warzone and Black Ops 6, and it adds a bunch of content for the Call of Duty games.

Here is a rundown of what's available:

  • 2 operator skins
  • 3 weapon blueprints
  • 1 weapon charm
  • Finishing Move and 2 Loading Screens
  • Spray and Large Decal
  • 2XP Token (1 hour) and 2WXP token (1 hour)

In other Call of Duty news, the Black Ops 7 multiplayer beta is available until October 9, while a free trial for Black Ops 6 goes live that day as well to coincide with the debut of Season 6 and The Haunting.

This is all happening right around the time of rival Battlefield 6's launch on October 10.

It's not just Game Pass subscribers who get special perks for Call of Duty, as PlayStation Plus members also receive exclusive DLC from time to time.

Game Pass underwent a significant upheaval recently, as Microsoft raised the price of Game Pass Ultimate by 50%, from $20/month to $30/month. The price hike has generated a lot of lively discussion and debate, and Microsoft itself has admitted that price hikes are not fun for anyone.

The next wave of Xbox Game Pass releases have been announced, and it includes three day-one new releases.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Here's a proper look at Starseeker: Astroneer Expeditions and its spacey, co-operative gameplay
item.content:encoded:
The final... funtier? I'm not convinced by this one either

How about a fresh look at Starseeker: Astroneer Expeditions, that not-an-Astroneer-sequel from System Era? The developer revealed an extended look at gameplay yesterday, detailing what it is you'll be doing exactly. As has already been established, it's an online co-op game, one of those "friendslop" kind of games you'll see people be mean about on Ditter and TikTok comments. To be specific, you can play it solo, or with three of your friends, but there are elements that draw on other players (more on that in a bit).

Like a lot of These Kinds Of Games (we really should agree on a name for them at this point), to start off you'll have to prepare for the challenge ahead. You do this on the titular S.S. Starseeker, a big ole ship filled with a bunch of other cutely designed also titularly titled Astroneers. Here, you'll buy and craft different tools and items to bring with you, and decide what it is you want to take with you on expeditions. That might be something useful, or, if you're that kind of person who just likes to goof around while everyone else actually has fun playing the game, you could bring a beach ball instead.

Expeditions! Structurally these sound pretty par for the course. You land on a planet, you go do a mission or a task or somesuch, and you get back before your oxygen runs out. Along the way there might be alien creatures to do battle with, bits of loot to plunder, that sort of thing.

The Astroneery element of it all is that you have a terrain tool that you can modify in different ways. At its base you just remove terrain, but different nozzles can make it shoot out water, build up the land, launch aliens or yourself into the sky, etc.

There's no procedural generation to be found on the planets you visit either, the main one the game is launching with, Tefra, was made by hand, so you'll be able to revisit particular locations from expedition to expedition. As you progress, you'll also unlock more landing zones to other parts of the planet, which subsequently have tougher challenges to face.

These challenges might include something simple like repairing some equipment, or bringing up a receiver to a high point on the map. Some of them might even encourage you to work with other groups of players to complete them, a point I quite like - there's not enough online games about collaboration out there!

No exact release date just yet, but Starseeker: Astroneer Expeditions is due out some time in 2026.



https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/heres-a-proper-look-at-starseeker-astroneer-expeditions-and-its-spacey-co-operative-gameplay

item.title: Game Pass Adds The Grinch: Christmas Adventures After Big Price Hike
item.content:encoded:
Microsoft has announced the the first list of games being added to Xbox Game Pass since the service‚Äôs unpopular price hike news rolled out last week. It includes The Grinch: Christmas Adventures ‚Äì Merry & Mischievous Edition, the update to a 2023 co-op holiday adventure that I‚Äôm sure fans have been waiting for.

The ‚Äúfestive platformer‚Äù has you searching for collectibles, snowboarding down Mount Crumpit, and even parachuting through Whoville. Apparently that was not enough to impress many of the only 27 people who reviewed the $40 Steam version. ‚ÄúThis game is BAD!‚Äù wrote one. ‚ÄúQuite terrible all things considered,‚Äù wrote another. ‚ÄúThe original game from the 90‚Äôs was a world play style game with objectives and missions‚Ä¶this is a game for a 5 year old.‚Äù

Don‚Äôt let that completely dissuade you from checking it out though! Here‚Äôs everything coming to the various, newly priced tiers of Game Pass in October 2025:

  • Supermarket Simulator (Cloud, Console, and PC) ‚Äì October 8
    Game Pass Ultimate, Game Pass Premium, PC Game Pass
  • Baldur‚Äôs Gate and Baldur‚Äôs Gate II: Enhanced Editions (PC) ‚Äì October 9
    Game Pass Ultimate, Game Pass Premium, PC Game Pass
  • The Casting of Frank Stone (Cloud, PC, and Xbox Series X|S) ‚Äì October 14
    Game Pass Ultimate, Game Pass Premium, PC Game Pass
  • Ball x Pit (Cloud, Console, and PC) ‚Äì October 15
    Game Pass Ultimate, PC Game Pass
  • The Grinch: Christmas Adventures (Cloud, Console, and PC) ‚Äì October 15
    Game Pass Ultimate, Game Pass Premium, PC Game Pass
  • Eternal Strands (Cloud, PC, and Xbox Series X|S) ‚Äì October 15
    Now with Game Pass Premium
  • He Is Coming (Game Preview) (PC) ‚Äì October 15
    Now with Game Pass Premium
  • Ninja Gaiden 2 Black (Cloud, PC, and Xbox Series X|S) ‚Äì October 15
    Now with Game Pass Premium
  • Pax Dei (PC) ‚Äì October 16
    Game Pass Ultimate, Game Pass Premium, PC Game Pass
  • Keeper (Cloud, PC, and Xbox Series X|S) ‚Äì October 17
    Game Pass Ultimate, PC Game Pass
  • Evil West (Cloud, Console, and PC) ‚Äì October 21
    Game Pass Ultimate, Game Pass Premium, PC Game Pass
  • Ninja Gaiden 4 (Cloud, PC, and Xbox Series X|S) ‚Äì October 21
    Game Pass Ultimate, PC Game Pass

That is 12 games in total, and some of them are shaping up to be quite good, especially Ninja Gaiden 4. But it‚Äôs also worth noting that only three of these games require Game Pass Ultimate. The rest are all available with Game Pass Premium or Game Pass PC. This is the last batch hitting before the new $30-a-month price hits most Ultimate subscribers on November 4, so while Microsoft might be trying to win players over with a few surprises in November, this month is mostly what we expected it to be.

The three games leaving Game Pass on October 15 are Cocoon, Core Keeper, and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutants Unleashed. Cocoon in particular is an outstanding puzzle adventure you can finish in just a couple of sittings. If you haven‚Äôt given it a try or already beaten it, I highly recommend checking it out in the next week before it‚Äôs gone.



https://kotaku.com/game-pass-october-2025-ninja-gaiden-grinch-price-2000633269

item.title: LG Has Clearance Vibes as 27‚Ä≥ UltraGear Gaming Monitor Hits Its Cheapest Ever to Compete With Samsung Deals
item.content:encoded:
Prime Day deals are going in full swing, making it a great time to invest in a gaming monitor. If you‚Äôve been looking for something feature-packed at a more approachable price, we‚Äôve just spotted the 27-inch LG UltraGear QHD gaming monitor going for $297 on Amazon, which is a 41% discount off its regular price.

This is a significant drop, but it‚Äôs only limited to Prime users at the moment. Non-Prime users can snag it up for $349, which is also a nice $151 off. Prime members also enjoy free delivery, but just be sure to get your orders in soon. The retailer has marked it as a limited-time deal, and we won‚Äôt be surprised if it expires soon.

See at Amazon

Better Color Accuracy on a Massive Screen

The 27-inch screen size is quite spacious, offering a decent 2560√ó1440 QHD resolution. The IPS panel offers vibrant colors, exceptional contrast, and impressive detail ‚Äì all of which come together to create an immersive gaming or streaming experience. It also supports VESA DisplayHDR 400 and covers up to 95% of the DCI-P3 color gamut, so you can expect deeper blacks and more visual accuracy. There‚Äôs an ultra-fast 1ms (GtG) response time, paired with a 240Hz refresh rate to keep slowdowns and lags at bay. Racing past opponents or engaging in competitive matches where every second counts; this monitor won‚Äôt disappoint.

It‚Äôs officially G-SYNC Compatible and also supports AMD FreeSync Premium. You can choose a GPU without worrying about screen tearing or stutter. Connectivity options are plenty ‚Äì HDMI 2.1, DisplayPort 1.4, and a 4-pole headphone out that supports DTS Headphone:X. The stand is also adjustable, so you can play around with tilt and height to get the right viewing angle for yourself. This is also great for setups that multiple people use. You don‚Äôt really have to settle for an awkward angle while trying to make it work for you.

LG also includes an Enhanced Gaming GUI that lets you choose between display presets like Gamer, FPS, or RTS modes for an even better view.

All in all, this deal gets you an impressive, high-resolution gaming monitor for less. If you‚Äôre a Prime member, you can get it for under $300. Non-prime members are in luck, too, since they can grab one for $349, which is still a good discount on a model this packed. It‚Äôs a limited-time discount, so if you‚Äôve been thinking of making the upgrade, we recommend grabbing it as soon as you can.

item.title: Dead Space Fans Slam $35 Isaac Clarke Costume In EA's New Skate
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Fans of the Dead Space series have expressed strong dissatisfaction over the pricing of a new crossover bundle in EA's free-to-play title, Skate, currently in early access. The bundle features a cardboard-style Isaac Clarke costume, a themed skateboard, the Necro Stomp emote, and several stickers. The bundle is priced at 3,350 San Van Bucks, the game's virtual currency, but the pricing structure forces players to spend a minimum of $35 to acquire the necessary in-game funds. While a USG Ishimura T-shirt is available for free, the cost of the full bundle has drawn criticism for being excessive.

While this isn't the first collab between Dead Space and Skate, as there was a free Isaac Clarke skin in Skate 3, the new bundle has continued the debate over microtransaction practices. Some players drew comparisons between the original Skate 3 unlockable and this new version, pointing out that when the costume was free, it felt more like a fun Easter egg than a monetized item. However, others have suggested the new costume's exaggerated cardboard look may be intentional, aiming for a Halloween costume aesthetic rather than a direct replica of Isaac Clarke's iconic armor. Even so, the $35 price tag remains a sore point.

On the left is Isaac Clarke from Dead Space in Skate 3. Model looks incredible & could only be obtained through a cheat code.

On the right is an Issac Clarke outfit in a bundle (pic included of bundle) on Skate 4. It costs roughly $30-$40 and looks horrible.

Idek what to say‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/G4dd9Y76jr

‚Äî SirBlackout (@BlackoutTV_) October 7, 2025

However, not all community feedback has been negative. One Reddit user offered a more nuanced view of the game's direction: "On the one hand, I do get it. I would definitely have preferred this game to be a traditional, single-player Skate game where everything is included in the purchase price. On the other hand, I've been playing and loving the new Skate. You do get tons of cosmetics for free if the virtual dress-up part of the game is your bag. The biggest downside is that you only get a handful of items for free that are from real skating brands."

The user went on to say they paid $25 for the Supporter Pack and felt the overall value was strong, citing access to branded items and a surprisingly generous season pass system. "A traditional Skate was never going to happen these days, so if it took being F2P to get made, I'd rather have this than nothing, as there is a lack of good skating games these days."

Reactions online have reflected a mix of disappointment and cynicism. "Let's hope that one day Dead Space will reach a state as an IP that it isn‚Äôt solely relegated to just being a skin in a mediocre always-online game to boost microtransactions," another Redditor wrote.

Another fan on Twitter commented, "You can buy three Dead Space games with that money (and probably three Skate games)." While some appreciate the ongoing crossover between two beloved EA properties, many argue that the current execution--and its pricing--detract from what could have been a celebratory moment for both franchises.

Still, the pricing has stirred frustration among Dead Space fans in particular, many of whom are disheartened by the franchise's uncertain future. Despite the critical success of the 2023 Dead Space remake, EA has reportedly shelved plans for a Dead Space 2 remake and a potential Dead Space 4, reassigning developer Motive to the Battlefield franchise. Since then, Isaac Clarke has been relegated to cameo appearances in other games like Fortnite and Battlefield 2042.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Cronos: The New Dawn Nintendo Switch 2 1.4 Update Brings Significant Visual Improvements
item.content:encoded:
Cronos: The New Dawn has been significantly improved on Nintendo Switch 2 by a new patch that went live this week.

According to a new report shared on X by SuperMetalDave64, the 1.4 update introduces significant visual improvements, including improved texture quality, LOD draw distance, and lighting and fog with less light bleed. Even at a glance, these visual improvements are easily spottable and bring the Nintendo Switch 2 version of the game closer to the other console versions of the survival horror game developed by Bloober Team.

SuperMetalDave64 also shared a quick comparison between the 1.3 version, the new 1.4 version and the max settings PC version of Cronos: The New Dawn. This side-by-side comparison clearly highlights the improvements which make the Switch 2 version a more palatable choice than at launch.

Cronos: The New Dawn leverages a lot on its visuals to create the haunting experience that defines the game, so the improvements introduced in the Nintendo Switch 2 version of the game effectively improve the whole game on the system. You can learn more about how the game's atmosphere makes for one of Bloober Team's best games by checking out my review.

Cronos: The New Dawn is now available worldwide on PC, PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S, and Nintendo Switch 2.

item.title: Crusader Kings III All Under Heaven Expansion Revealed for Later This Month
item.content:encoded:
Developer and publisher Paradox has announced a brand new Crusader Kings III expansion by the name of All Under Heaven, and it's taking things in an Easterly direction later this month.

All Under Heaven is the latest major expansion for Crusader Kings III, following on from April's Khans of the Steppe, and it's introducing settings and campaigns that are entirely new to the series, so you're pretty much guaranteed never to have experienced them in a Crusader Kings game before.

As the name suggests, All Under Heaven will bring "detailed representations of medieval China, Japan and Southeast Asia", and each new playable nation will bring brand new mechanics for you to grapple with.

Nations included as part of All Under Heaven include Japan, China, and a Southeast Asian empire, and you'll be able to enjoy new mechanics like the Celestial government system (which is unique to the Chinese civilization), Tributary Missions, and the Silk Road, the latter of which will allow you to prosper like never before.

Paradox is promising that this expansion will build on Crusader Kings III "on a monumental scale", so this isn't just a minor DLC pack; it's a full-throated expansion that should augment your experience with the game significantly.

You can check out the debut trailer for the Crusader Kings III All Under Heaven expansion right here.

If you're unfamiliar with Crusader Kings III, it's the third major entry in the Crusader Kings series of grand strategy games, and like its predecessors, it tasks you with playing as a dynasty and attempting to survive the slings and arrows of Middle Ages politics.

It's proven pretty popular with players, too, racking up four million sales at last count despite being available on Game Pass (although that may not be the boon it once was thanks to recent changes).

You can check out Crusader Kings III right now on PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He‚Äôs originally an‚Ä¶ More about Joseph

item.title: Soul Injector Commando is a fever dream's fever dream about a dead guy firing humanity into billionaires
item.content:encoded:
They fell for the old fake meteorite ruse, idiots

It's pointless me trying to sum this game up before you've clapped the lips of your eyes around it and taken a long drag. There's a trailer below. Do it now. Nod if you've done so. Right, that was Soul Injector Commando, a video game about shooting some semblance of everyday humanity into the bodies of the billionaires who're behind all of the world's problems.

You are the Soul Injector Commando, brought back from the dead by god themselves and sent to a bunker. All of the rich bellends have been handily lured there by an audacious fake meteorite prank worthy of enshrinement atop the YouTube algorithm until the end of time. You romp through, soul injecting until you can soul inject no more.

There a nine levels to get through, filled with these malcontents who'll "become normal humans, get normal jobs, and be happy" if you succeed. At your disposal are a number of different weapons and upgrades, fully voice acted dialogue I assume will help you tell them the error of their ways, and time trials to try if you get through a bout of soul injecting and decide you'd like to try that level again.

And, to be frank, why wouldn't you? I can't see the likes of being assembled by a dino head with six arms, blasting your way through a supermarket while coins flick around and a big bowl guy waves a gloved hand in joy/resignation, or driving a tiny SUV with wings getting old quickly. Ditto splattering execs as a sentient golf ball, encountering what looks like an intergalactic skeletal drummer, or fighting whatever the head thing that pops up around the minute mark is. I've not even mentioned the two-headed butterfly knight creature.

To bring us back down to Earth a bit, Soul Injector Commando's the latest work of developer and artist Jeremy Couillard, who's got a well-honed knack for the surreal. AlienAfterlife, JEF, Fuzz Dungeon, Escape From Lavender Island, and the snappily-named Sometimes to Deal with the Difficulty of Being Alive, I Need to Believe There Is a Possibility That Life Is Not Real. They're all now on my wishlist, and not solely because their art styles are 90% made up of things that my uncle's prog rock band would've given anything to put on their album covers.

Soul Injector Commando doesn't have a release date yet. It strikes me as the kind of game that'll just rock up instantly whenever the universe needs it to. Until then, you can wishlist it on Steam.



https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/soul-injector-commando-is-a-fever-dreams-fever-dream-about-a-dead-guy-firing-humanity-into-billionaires

item.title: Netflix Just Made The Whole Mess Over Henry Cavill Leaving The Witcher Even Weirder
item.content:encoded:
Was Netflix‚Äôs The Witcher trying to give Cavill the boot as early as season 2? Did Borderlands 4 cut one of the previous game‚Äôs most unpopular characters during development? And why is Atari making it harder to play an all-time classic on PC? It‚Äôs another edition of Morning Checkpoint, Kotaku‚Äòs daily roundup of gaming news and culture. Craft breweries are apparently on the decline, the surest sign yet that the millennial zeitgeist is dying. This is not a good thing. I am also part of the problem, having traded my beloved Hazy IPAs at the local bar for cheap pounders from the grocery store.

The original System Shock 2 is disappearing from stores thanks to the remaster

As spotted by Rock, Paper, Shotgun, the 1999 sci-fi immersive sim classic will be delisted from PC storefronts on October 10. From that point forward, the only way to access it will be as part of the 25th anniversary remaster. The original game was just $10 to buy individually, but will cost $30 to access as part of the remaster. ‚ÄúExisting owners of System Shock 2 (1999) will still be able to re-download and play it from their library, but new users will no longer be able to purchase System Shock 2 (1999) as a standalone product,‚Äù reads a notice from publisher Atari.

Netflix deletes an important date in its report about Liam Hemsworth taking over for Henry Cavill in The Witcher

Either that's typo or that Henry Cavill shit was even messier than we think, because season 2 premiered in 2021 and Cavill didn't even announce he was leaving until the end of 2022 https://t.co/v2pHao4f5k

‚Äî Paul Tassi (@PaulTassi) October 7, 2025

The streaming company published its own profile of Hemsworth alongside a Witcher season 4 trailer, but it included a very curious detail. According to the original version of the article, Hemsworth was first contacted about taking over the role back in 2020. That was between when season 1 and 2 aired, and two years before Cavill was officially replaced. This data point might add more fuel to the intrigue surrounding his messy departure, but Netflix has now gone back and deleted the date from the profile altogether without any explanation. So now it‚Äôs definitely fueling more intrigue.

A controversial Borderlands 3 character was seemingly cut from the sequel

Alright I guess we're gonna talk about it:

AVA WAS CUT FROM BORDERLANDS 4

There are numerous files related to her in the game, more specifically outlining that she was completely replaced by Amara late in development. This means yes, she was originally going to team up with‚Ä¶ https://t.co/QF8ESnQp0p pic.twitter.com/tBoVNJ8hpq

‚Äî EpicNNG (@EpicNNG) October 6, 2025

Ava debuted in Borderlands 3 as Vault Hunter Maya‚Äôs apprentice. Many players did not like her and were relieved she did not return in Borderlands 4. But new datamining of the files suggests that might have not always been the plan. File names suggest her role may have been replaced by the new Vault Hunter Amara, indicating Gearbox was paying very close attention to feedback from the last game when trying to nail the new one‚Äôs story, which it mostly does.

Sony is siding with Battlefield 6 now that Microsoft owns Call of Duty

Battlefield 6 Marketing With PlayStation Kicks Off:#Battlefield6

Hollywood, US: pic.twitter.com/lssW3IpMp5

‚Äî @Zuby_Tech (@Zuby_Tech) October 7, 2025

Battlefield 6 ads are out in full force this week and people have spotted many of them with promotions for PlayStation 5, Push Square reports. The irony is that Sony spent much of the PS4 console generation and this one paying Activision extra to promote its platform as the best place to play Call of Duty, complete with exclusive early access and other perks. Microsoft has promised versions of new entries in the series would have platform parity and Sony, understandably, now has little interest in helping to promote its rival‚Äôs biggest blockbuster.

Battlefield 6 appears to be always-online

That‚Äôs according to Does It Play, which reports that the game needs an internet connection to work, even for the main campaign, even though the data appears to technically come the PS5 disc. Bummer!

The Outer Worlds 2‚Äòs opening area can keep you busy for over 12 hours

Game Informer has a new deep dive on the upcoming RPG shooter alongside 19 minutes of new gameplay. Design director Matt Singh said players can mainline the sequel‚Äôs main story ‚Äúfairly quickly‚Äù but that each biome will have plenty of side-content to offer fans who are interested in taking their time. The first, Paradise Island, will take over 12 hours to exhaust, with other biomes being ‚Äúnot much smaller.‚Äù

  • Zelda Williams is fed up with people sending her AI slop of her dad
  • Tron: Ares is another Disney cash-in devoid of humanity
  • Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3‚Äôs head of publishing calls bullshit on Elon Musk‚Äôs AI game

item.title: Discord Hackers Claim To Have 1.5TB Of Age Verification Photos
item.content:encoded:
Details of the recent Discord data hack continue to paint a darker picture for the company and its users. According to Discord news source Discord Previews, the group taking responsibility for the compromise claims to have an enormous amount of user data, specifically millions of user photos.

In a post on social media Discord Previews said that ‚Äúthe perpetrators of this attack claim to have obtained 1.5 TB of age-verification photos totalling 2,185,151 images.‚Äù It was added that the stolen data is being used, as with most instances like this, to ‚Äúextort Discord‚Äù.

On October 3, Discord publicly announced that an ‚Äúunauthorized party compromised one of Discord‚Äôs third-party customer service providers.‚Äù This incident, which happened in late September, had the following data impacted:

  • Name, Discord username, email, and other contact details if provided to Discord customer support
  • Limited billing information, such as payment type, the last four digits of your credit card, and purchase history, if associated with your account
  • IP addresses
  • Messages with our customer service agents 
  • Limited corporate data (training materials, internal presentations)

Information such as full credit card and CCV numbers, private messages, passwords, and other authentication data wasn‚Äôt involved.

According to Discord‚Äôs own policies, ID submissions are supposed to be deleted after age verification is complete.

‚ÄúDiscord and k-ID do not permanently store personal identity documents or your video selfies,‚Äù they say. ‚ÄúThe image of your identity document and the ID face match selfie are deleted directly after your age group is confirmed, and the video selfie used for facial age estimation never leaves your device.‚Äù

Insider Gaming has reached out to Discord for comment on how the company is looking to move forward and why so many age-verification photos were still within the company‚Äôs database. Should a response be received, it will be added to this story.

What do you think of the Discord hack leaving millions of user photos and information exposed? Leave your thoughts down in the comments below, and join the official Insider Gaming Discord server.

For more Insider Gaming, check out what games were the best-selling titles for August 2025. And don‚Äôt forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.
